Study Selection
Study identification, screening and selection are summarized in Figure 1.
Study identification, screening and selection are summarized in Figure 1.

Sleep Disturbance by Noise: Individual Studies
ORs for the probability of being highly sleep disturbed by noise for each study are shown in Figure 3 (aircraft), Figure 4 (road traffic), and Figure 5 (railway).
Note: CI, confidence interval; df, degrees of freedom; , nighttime noise; NORAH, Noise-Related Annoyance, Cognition and Health.Figure 4.
Note: CI, confidence interval; df, degrees of freedom; , nighttime noise; NORAH, Noise-Related Annoyance, Cognition and Health.Figure 5.
ORs for the probability of being highly sleep disturbed by noise for each study are shown in Figure 3 (aircraft), Figure 4 (road traffic), and Figure 5 (railway).

Exposure–Response Curves: Questions Specifically Mentioning Noise
The exposure–response curves for the probability of being highly sleep disturbed, derived using data from questions that specifically mentioned noise, are given in Figure 6.

Note: CI, confidence interval; , nighttime noise; WHO, World Health Organization.We compared the updated exposure–response curves to curves derived using only the 11 new studies published since the WHO review19 (Figure 7).
Note: , nighttime noise; WHO, World Health Organization.The exposure–response curves calculated in the original WHO review19 are given in Figure 6.
The exposure–response curves for the probability of being highly sleep disturbed, derived using data from questions that specifically mentioned noise, are given in Figure 6.
We compared the updated exposure–response curves to curves derived using only the 11 new studies published since the WHO review19 (Figure 7).
The exposure–response curves calculated in the original WHO review19 are given in Figure 6.

Exposure–Response Curves: Questions Not Specifically Mentioning Noise
The exposure–response curves for the probability of being highly sleep disturbed, derived using data from general sleep questions that did not specifically mention noise, are given in Figure 8.

With increasing , there was a small increase in disturbance for all questions, although the gradient of the exposure–response curves was generally smaller compared with questions that mentioned noise (Figure 6).
The differences between the three traffic modes were also less clear compared with questions mentioning noise (Figure 6).
The exposure–response curves for the probability of being highly sleep disturbed, derived using data from general sleep questions that did not specifically mention noise, are given in Figure 8.

With increasing , there was a small increase in disturbance for all questions, although the gradient of the exposure–response curves was generally smaller compared with questions that mentioned noise (Figure 6).
The differences between the three traffic modes were also less clear compared with questions mentioning noise (Figure 6).

When the sleep disturbance outcomes were combined for each traffic mode separately, the resulting exposure–response curves for road and railway noise were very similar to those calculated in the WHO review (Figure 6).

When the sleep disturbance outcomes were combined for each traffic mode separately, the resulting exposure–response curves for road and railway noise were very similar to those calculated in the WHO review (Figure 6).
